thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn urges Labour supporters not to 'give up' | UK | News | Express.co.uk
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn urges Labour supporters not to 'give up' | UK | News | Express.co.uk

author: Tom Martin
title: Jeremy Corbyn urges Labour supporters not to 'give up' | UK | News | Express.co.uk
text:
Jeremy Corbyn takes his 'share of responsibility' for Labour's by-election defeat Jeremy Corbyn takes his 'share of responsibility' for Labour's by-election defeat BELEAGURED Jeremy Corbyn took his share of the blame for Labour's poll flop for the first time - but insisted it is "not the time to run away." PUBLISHED: 17:47, Sun, Feb 26, 2017 | UPDATED: 18:07, Sun, Feb 26, 2017 
In a stumbling speech to Scottish Labour 's spring conference the UK leader also admitted last week's humiliating by-election defeat to the Tories in Copeland was "disappointing". 
The Left-winger attempted to rally the party faithful in Perth claiming its policies are "needed more than ever" as he launched an attack on Nicola Sturgeon 's SNP government. 
Mr Corbyn insisted it had "a record to be ashamed of" listing a litany of failures on NHS, education, and transport, as he warned "there is no appetite" for another independence referendum. Related articles Jeremy Corbyn slaps down SNP as he attempts to rally Labour Party 
But in an embarrassing gaffe during the rambling 33 minute address, he mistakenly thanked Ms Sturgeon's party instead of his own after Scottish leader Kezia Dugdale unveiled plans to increase child benefit on Saturday. 
He told delegates at Perth Concert Hall: "Well done Scottish Labour and well done our SNPs... MSPs for keeping that up." 
He almost repeated the same mistake seconds later before correcting himself to laughter. WENN Jeremy Corbyn admitted that the by-election defeat in Copeland was 'disappointing' 
Earlier, Mr Corbyn described the Copeland result as "deeply disappointing". Now is not the time to retreat, to run away or to give up Jeremy Corbyn 
He added: "Of course I take my share of responsibility for it. 
"We haven't done enough yet to rebuild trust. Corbyn looks crushed following by-election defeat Fri, February 24, 2017 Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn leaves his home following a humiliating blow by the Conservatives after snatching Copeland in a by-election victory. The struggling politician was talking on the day his party lost a by-election to the government, the first time this has happened in over 30 years. Adam Gray / SWNS.com 1 of 10 Jeremy Corbyn is seen at Savoy Place in London where the Labour leader was giving a speech on Brexit 
"But now is not the time to retreat, to run away or to give up." 
He went onto attack the Conservatives claiming "the nasty party is a back with a vengeance". 
But he criticised the SNP for talking "Left in opposition but when in power they go Right". 
He also accused it of "using Brexit as their leverage" for independence while polling has shown "there is no appetite for another referendum". 
The Islington North MP also repeated claims separation would lead to "turbo charged austerity" and "the case the SNP presented has weakened" since 2014. WENN Speaking at the Scottish Labour's spring conference, he urged Labour supporters not 'to give up' 
Attacking it for not using Holyrood's new powers to hike taxes further he said: "It reveals a party intent on stoking up grievance and blaming others for their own mistakes because they've taken their eye off the ball." 
He insisted Labour's ideas were those "whose time has come" adding: "But to win that fight we need to remain united." 
The plea came amid further meltdown in the party with former deputy leader Harriet Harman saying it has returned to the "painful" days of the 1980s. 
Meanwhile, in a bizarre intervention, his deputy leader Tom Watson said it was not "a suicide approach" to stick with the hapless Mr Corbyn. GETTY Kezia Dugdale unveiled plans to increase child benefit yesterday 
And further evidence that the party is in denial came from Baroness Shami Chakrabarti who blamed a series of different things for the defeat in Copeland including the BBC, former MP Jamie Reed, the weather and nuclear energy but refused to pin any responsibility on Mr Corbyn. 
But Mr Reed, who was a leading Labour moderate MP but quit because of Mr Corbyn's leadership said the current leader and Baroness Chakrabarti are "the epitome" of why voters are abandoning Labour. 
Responding to Mr Corbyn's speech, SNP deputy leader Angus Roberstson accused Labour of "grossly disrespecting" Scots' will to remain in Europe. 
He said: "Jeremy Corbyn's message is a stark and depressing surrender on a hard Brexit." All the pictures from Copeland by-election Fri, February 24, 2017
